Issues.Title: slow performance on google page speed due to zone.js
Issues.Body:
I Use angular7 as ssr, and we found out that our application has heavy and serious problems with google page speed and all the issues are funnelling to zone.js

Page speed complain about the script valuation is too high, after breaking down the app, we found the issues were related to polyfills, however, polyfills only containing

```
  import 'zone.js/dist/zone.js';  // Included with Angular CLI.
  import 'classlist.js/classList.min.js';
  import 'web-animations-js/web-animations.min.js';
```

then what we did was totally remove all the content on polyfills file, leave it empty, and add those files, directly from a cdn on the bottom of index.html as:

```
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/zone.js/0.9.1/zone.min.js"></script>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/classlist/1.2.201711092/classList.min.js"></script>
```

and the result was the same, the page speed still complaining about script valuation, however, we manage to reduce 50% of the script valuation, however, still and is really bad.

we were using a zone.js@0.8.10 then we upgrade to latest but nothing. Same result.

In fact, this is affecting all our apps no matter if we build as aot or server-side render, the result is the same.

Does anyone know how to solve this issue with page speed? Our ranking is below 20 over 100 as SSR.

This doesn't make any sense, it supposes to be faster, not slower?
I also try
`<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/zone.js/0.9.1/zone-evergreen.min.js"></script>`

Issues.Title: ngcc - handle deep imports during dependency resolution
Issues.Body:
Recently we have been failing to compile some ngcc target packages because the package has a deep import into another package. Previously we would log this with a warning but continue regardless. Now ngcc appears to crash instead.

In the case that the deeply imported package is not even an Angular compiled library, it makes not difference whether the package is imported deeply or not.

Ngcc should be more resilient to this kind of thing. In particular it should walk up the directory tree to find the nearest package.json and use that as the entry-point - possibly warning that this is a deep import.

Examples of this behaviour are `ngx-swiper-wrapper` (https://github.com/zefoy/ngx-swiper-wrapper/issues/226) and `delonabc` (https://github.com/mgechev/ngcc-validation/issues/110).

Issues.Title: [Feature Request] Angular Lite (single file components)
Issues.Body:
**The problem:**

It seems everywhere I look, front end frameworks have an obsession with vendor lock in by ensuring business logic is located inside of the front end framework.

Angular has a custom DI solution to help get your business logic talking to other islands of business logic. Angular's DI also helps put that logic into your components. 

While it's pretty good, it is a unique style of DI and has limitations. Limitations like a lack of dependency inversion. We depend on concrete implementations, and as a result there is a testing suite built by the Angular team to facilitate this.

_What I **love**, and I mean absolutely **love**_ about Angular is how phenomenal its templating syntax is. I'm not joking, it's honestly the most ergonomic expression of presentational concerns I have ever worked with.

What I dislike is that when I write an application, it's an Angular application. Not a TypeScript application which uses Angular as a renderer.

**The solution:**

This was briefly touched on in a conference given a while back, but I just wanted to add my 5 cents to the discussion.

Using decorators (for context-style DI), constructor injection and a simple mount/unmount system where everything is focused around components.

Here is an example of what I would love to see:
https://gist.github.com/alshdavid/32fdc1c39477910b4e5d6bc28630a269

Here is a running examle of this pattern being implemented in React
https://stackblitz.com/edit/react-ts-biohay?file=gui%2Fapp.tsx

Issues.Title: AsyncTestZoneSpec is needed for the async() test helper
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report
Running a single unit test with: `ng test --main src/app/any.component.spec.ts` causes an unexpected error where running all tests with `ng test` runs without error.

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [x] test
```

### Is this a regression?
Yes, running single .spec files with `--main` typically ran the tests within that file.

## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction
create a new project (Angular 8.2.1) with `ng new project`
run `ng test --main src/app/app.component.spec.ts`

## 🔥 Exception or Error

> Error: AsyncTestZoneSpec is needed for the async() test helper but could not be found. Please make sure that your environment includes zone.js/dist/async-test.js


## 🌍 Your Environment
Chrome 76
MacOS 10.14.6
Angular CLI: 8.2.1
Node: 12.8.0
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: De-Optimize bundle size when needed. Lazy Loading, common.js
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->
```
- [x] build
```

my feature request would be a regression of this feature: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6204

When I declare "stuff" (pipes, directives, components, services) in **AT LEAST TWO** lazy loaded modules a optimization takes places and the "stuff" ends up in **common.js** bundle.

That's desired in most cases, but ...

### Description

Lets take this architecture:


```
root.module

lazy1.module
    secretComponent
    secretDirective

lazy2.module
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

this will result in

```
common.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

my **desired outcome** would be redundant code duplication:

```
no secrets in common.js

lazy1.chunk.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective

lazy2.chunk.js
    secretComponent
    secretDirective
```

The trivia behind this is that my webserver can block the serving of lazyModules based on auth. and I don't want unauth. users to get the sources for `secret.* "stuff"`.

How can I control what "stuff" lands inside common.js.

### Describe the solution you'd like

My first reaction would be an additional parameter in the modules decorator:


```
. . .
  declarations: [ 
    secretComponent
    secretDirective],
  imports: [MaterialModule],
  providers: [
    secretService
  ],
  bootstrap: [secretComponent],

  keepInModule: [
    secretComponent,
    secretDirective,
    secretService,
  ]
. . .
```

Code declarations that are always added to `keepInModule` will not end up in common.js but will be duplicated to the lazyModulesChunks.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ✍️--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Not sure how to archive this with angular-cli

### Some thoughs :boom: 

Since we could provide a service `secretService` solely in let say "secretComponent" we probably need something like `keepInComponent` ... not sure how to handle this case ...

Issues.Title: mat-autocomplete with optgroups report n of 0 items in a list when using a screenreader (Accessibility)
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/angular/jepgrkeyqbr?file=app%2Fautocomplete-optgroup-example.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Turn your screenreader on on Chrome OS (usually Ctrl + Alt +Z)
2. Navigate/tab to the autocomplete.
3. Once expanded, start scrolling using the arrow keys.
4. Keep track of what the screen reader is announcing.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
It should read "**Option Name** List Item x of y". X being the number of the option you are currently hovering on and y being the length of the group of options.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
It's reading "**Option Name** List Item n of 0". N being the number of the option in the list. This is inaccessible for users with screen readers since they have no insight to the list size or if they are approaching a new group.

**Screencap of this:** https://imgur.com/a/P7WlHQG

#### Environment

- CDK/Material: 8.1.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 76
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Chrome OS (76.0.3809.90)

Issues.Title: dialog: example prompts should follow Material Design guidance
Issues.Body:
I just noticed while looking at the overview of the Dialog component that the code sample illustrating dialog structure directives did not follow the Material Design guidelines regarding dialogs and alert dialogs.

For dialogs, avoid ambiguous questions as "Are you sure ?" (even though I'm aware that the dialog's title is "Delete all", but then we could just ask "Delete all elements ?" as a title).
Since the provided dialog surely resembles an alert dialog, the example should also provide some explicit action labels, like "Cancel" and "Delete" instead of "No" and "Yes".

I believe the examples provided in Angular Material's documentation should reflect Material Design guidelines.
I usually expect documentation examples to follow best practices, especially regarding a library as serious as Angular Material.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "dialog: example prompts should follow Material Design guidance" (#16746)
